item.title: Part 1: Time-series of marine aerosol optical depth (MAOD), chlorophyll concentration, sea ice, and wind speed.
item.description: The project represented herein is the first of an 4-part blog series on the manuscript, Multi-year Seasonal Trends in Sea Ice, Chlorophyll Concentration, and Marine Aerosol Optical Depth in the Bellingshausen Sea. This manuscript is my first first-author publication and represents the first chapter of my PhD encompassing numerous years of extensive work! I do not come from a remote sensing background and my lab also is not a remote sensing lab.

item.title: Part 2: Lagged Temporal Analysis, Bellingshausen Sea, western Antarctic
item.description: This is part 2 of the blog post series on the manuscript, Multi-year Seasonal Trends in Sea Ice, Chlorophyll Concentration, and Marine Aerosol Optical Depth in the Bellingshausen Sea. As written by my PI & co-author, Dr. Jeff S. Bowman, “One challenge that we faced was that CALIPSO represents data with high spatial resolution along a 2D path or ‘curtain.’ The orbital geometry is such that not every point on the globe gets covered; the same curtains get sampled every 16 days.

item.title: Part 3: Seasonal Spatial Correlation between Sea Ice & Chlorophyll Concentration
item.description: This is part 3 of the blog post series on the manuscript, Multi-year Seasonal Trends in Sea Ice, Chlorophyll Concentration, and Marine Aerosol Optical Depth in the Bellingshausen Sea. As a polar environment, the western Antarctic Peninsula region is subject to seasonal dynamics of varying light availability. We can visualize this seasonality: as predicted, sea ice is at its maximum extent in winter, and at its lowest in the summertime.

item.title: Part 4: Seasonal Spatial Correlation between Marine Aerosol Optical Depth (MAOD) & Sea Ice
item.description: This is part 4, the last of the blog post series on the manuscript, Multi-year Seasonal Trends in Sea Ice, Chlorophyll Concentration, and Marine Aerosol Optical Depth in the Bellingshausen Sea! In Part 3, we explored the fact that as a polar environment, the western Antarctic Peninsula and Bellingshausen Sea region is subject to seasonal dynamics of varying light & temperature. We can visualize that sea ice is at its maximum extent in winter, and at its lowest extent in the summertime.

item.title: Acquiring data from NASA Earth-observing satellites for Southern Ocean-scale analysis
item.description: One of the most important and time-consuming steps in conducting spatiotemporal analyses, ESPECIALLY that which uses satellite data, is to get these data, convert it into readable format, and confirm that the arrays are in the correct format, layout, etc. for further imaging and statistical processing. Without a doubt, in all of the analyses I’ve conducted, this has been the steepest learning curve, and even required an internship at NASA Langley to colloborate on how best to define calculation of new variables from raw data.

item.title: Southern Ocean-scale seasonal analysis
item.description: Before I qualified and moved forward to PhD Candidacy, I wanted to examine what happens if I do the earlier study across the entire Southern Ocean. Here I’ve compiled my code & figures for some preliminary data analysis mimicking methods from the earlier manuscript but zoomed out to the entire Southern Ocean. Variables assessed include marine aerosol optical depth (MAOD), depolarization ratio (sea ice), chlorophyll-a concentration, and wind speed. This research is still in the works, but what is interesting is that spatial clustering of MAOD & sea ice, MAOD & wind speed, and sea ice & chlorophyll-a concentration is significant, also seen in and supporting the prior study!
